0.text: Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them.

182.text: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.

216.text: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

246.text: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

256.text: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

302.text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.

348.text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

394.text: 6. Show your child that you care

401.text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

442.text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

473.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about talking about emotions?

546.text: Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"

597.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

618.text: Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"

643.text: Keep it positive. It normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

691.text: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!

724.text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that redirecting your children only works before or at the beginning of a bad behaviour.

752.text: You can also always type "Help" for more tips.

761.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!

780.text: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.

807.text: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.

833.text: 2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.

842.text: These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.

877.text: 3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

910.text: But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

924.text: 1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

938.text: 2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.

952.text: 3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you

962.text: 4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

982.text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!

1029.text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

1080.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them the rest of their lives. What a gift!

1115.text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum

1145.text: Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:

1154.text: Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room

1168.text: Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology

1178.text: Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day

1190.text: Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!

1211.text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.

1234.text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)

1248.text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)

1260.text: Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)

1275.text: 2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.

1302.text: 1. Realistic: Consider the age of your child

1310.text: 2. Immediate: Give them as soon as possible

1318.text: 3. Fair: Make sure the consequence is not too harsh

1328.text: 4. Consistent: Make sure you can follow through if you have to

1340.text: 5. The last resort: Try to encourage the positive behaviour to happen more often!

1354.text: 3. Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

1374.text: 4. When the behaviour ends, immediately redirect your child to a positive behaviour and praise them.

1390.text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

1410.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Using consequences can help teach children self-discipline, independence, decision-making, and responsibility. They help children learn that their actions will have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.

1466.text: This takes time AND patience. Normally the behaviour will get worse because your child will try to test your resolve. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

1498.text: It sometimes gets worse before it gets better. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific  behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

1531.text: Try to remain consistent and calm (you can even Take a Pause). Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

1558.text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention before ignoring

1567.text: 2. Only ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining and tantrums

1580.text: 3. Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention

1589.text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

1604.text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention and One-on-One Time

1619.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love when they have calmed down. Be patient. This is not easy. But you can do this!

1676.text: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

1775.text: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

1797.text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention

1804.text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

1814.text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child

1821.text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

1836.text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

1851.text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

1886.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.

1898.text: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!

1924.text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention

1931.text: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

1957.text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

1967.text: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

2007.text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

2014.text: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.

2033.text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

2053.text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.

2084.text: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

2112.text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

2148.text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

2158.text: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

2196.text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

2211.text: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

2256.text: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

2275.text: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

2316.text: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

2340.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support.

2356.text: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!

2397.text: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

2414.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to use ignore to reduce tantrums or other difficult behaviours?
